a.xlink:title:
Benoît Régent-Kloeckner
@BrKloeckner@piaille.fr
2023-03-22 10:03
--------------------------------
@barrygoldman1 @woody @csk
deeply, periodicity means that
we can recover the whole tiling
by a finite portion of it and
a finite set of rigid motions
(orientation-preserving or not) to
be applied repeatedly. It turns out
that if you can do that, you can do
that with a possibly bigger (but
still finite) portion of the tiling
and a finite set of translations.
a.text: we can recover the whole tiling
by a finite portion of it and
a finite set of rigid motions
be applied repeatedly. It turns out
that if you can do that, you can do
still finite) portion of the tiling
and a finite set of translations.

a.xlink:title:
Benoît Régent-Kloeckner
@BrKloeckner@piaille.fr
2023-03-22 10:04
--------------------------------
@barrygoldman1 @woody @csk So in
the end, the set of motions used in
the tiling and in the definition of
periodicity can be taken identical.
a.text: the end, the set of motions used in
the tiling and in the definition of

a.xlink:title:
Craig S. Kaplan
@csk
2023-03-21 14:51
--------------------------------
@otherthings @gregeganSF @tiotasram
A very good starting point for
further study of these statistical
noise properties would be this old
paper by Victor Ostromoukhov et
al.: http:/ / www.iro.umontreal.ca/
~ostrom/ ImportanceSampling/ .
They use the Penrose Tiling as
a scaffolding for importance
sampling. So you can count on
Fourier spectra characterizing
the blue noise and anisotropy.
a.text: A very good starting point for
noise properties would be this old
They use the Penrose Tiling as
sampling. So you can count on

a.xlink:title:
rjf_berger
@rjf_berger
2023-03-25 05:05
--------------------------------
@tiotasram @soulsource @csk Lagarias
wrote on quasiperiodic sets
(https:/ / dept.math.lsa.umich.edu/
~lagarias/ doc/ diffraction.pdf)
and their diffraction patterns. He
gives a general definition and if I
understand correctly there should
be both a finite upper and lower
bound to the gaps between the points
(sorry for my wild descriptions I am
no mathematician) of a quasiperiodic
lattice. This seems to be a valid
generalization to me of what one can
obtain from "cut and project".

I wonder about the gaps of the
zeta zeros. As far as I know there
are upper and lower bounds but
they do depend on the zeros, I
mean they are as far as I know no
constants. If one can fix this
somehow, say transform the zeta
function such that these bounds
become constants, I don't know.
a.text: gives a general definition and if I
be both a finite upper and lower
bound to the gaps between the points

generalization to me of what one can

mean they are as far as I know no
constants. If one can fix this

a.xlink:title:
Tiota Sram
@tiotasram@kolektiva.social
2023-03-25 13:23
--------------------------------
@rjf_berger you've gone a bit
beyond my math + physics level here,
and web search isn't proving useful
to figure out what a "quadratic
grid" is since it also appears
to name a teaching technique for
polynomial multiplication. If
you have a reference handy for
"quadratic grid" I'd appreciate
that, although I can keep searching
more carefully on my own.

The idea of slicing an n+1
dimensional repeating grid at an
irrational angle and projecting
the included points down to n
dimensions makes sense to me.

I saw some other papers referencing
a Fibonacci grid, but I'll have to
dig into that more, because they
glossed over the definition of the
Fibonacci grid and the paper they
cited for that didn't have a full
text I could access very easily.

But thanks for drawing
additional connections!

a.xlink:title:
Benoît Régent-Kloeckner
@BrKloeckner@piaille.fr
2023-03-22 09:55
--------------------------------
@barrygoldman1 @woody @csk You are
entitled to not liking it, but
this is still a huge achievement
crowning decades of efforts 😅
Most of the planes we meet and
use do sit in 3d space, allowing
to flip tiles. In particular,
inclusion of orientation-reversible
isometries does not prevent to
make a patchwork blanket with a
single model to cut out the tiles.
For a bathroom, you do have to cut
out two versions of the tiles.
a.text: entitled to not liking it, but
this is still a huge achievement
Most of the planes we meet and
use do sit in 3d space, allowing
make a patchwork blanket with a
single model to cut out the tiles.
For a bathroom, you do have to cut
out two versions of the tiles.

a.xlink:title:
Craig S. Kaplan
@csk
2023-03-21 13:52
--------------------------------
@tiotasram @soulsource That's
right! You can draw aperiodic
tilings using a sampling algorithm
that runs in constant time (but,
uh, with a high constant). I
don't think this is published
anywhere, but here are two
examples (one by me): https:/ /
www.shadertoy.com/ view/ XdtBzH
https:/ / www.shadertoy.com/ view/
ldcfzN, For a long time I've
thought about creating a more
efficient algorithm, but it's a
hard problem (it even seems to
connect somehow to lattice crypto).
a.text: uh, with a high constant). I
ldcfzN, For a long time I've

math break down here: https:/

least one logarithmic function.

other perspective in the second

people aren't nerdy enough? ;)

Craig S. Kaplan
@csk
2023-03-21 02:02
--------------------------------
In a new paper, David Smith,
Joseph Myers (@jsm28), Chaim
Goodman-Strauss and I prove
that a polykite that we call
"the hat" is an aperiodic
monotile, AKA an einstein. We
finally got down to 1! https:/ /
arxiv.org/ abs/ 2303.10798 4/ 6

would need mirrored versions.

a.xlink:title:
rjf_berger
@rjf_berger
2023-03-25 04:36
--------------------------------
@tiotasram @soulsource @csk The
method is sometimes called "cut and
project". Say you have 2d quadratic
grid and you draw a stripe of some
finite breadth and with irrational
slope into the grid. Then projeting
the gridpoints that come to fall
within the stripe onto a say central
line of the stripe you obtain a 1D
quasi periodic/ quasicrystalline
pattern. Like the sequence of
S and L in the penrose tiling.

The analog works for Dan Shechtmans
real world 3D quasicrystalls,
they can be described as an
irrational intersection of a
3D slath with a 4D periodic
(translational) tiling (pattern).

As far as I know it's open if
there are quasi periodic patterns
that cannot be described by "cut
and project". In any case the
basic idea can be used to compute
fourier tranforms, i. e. the
(electron) diffraction patterns
of the quasiperiodic patterns
that can be described like that.

Freeman Dyson wrote famously in
"From Birds and Frogs" about
the idea that the Riemann zeta
zeros could be 1D quasicrystals in
some sense and that a "complete
understanding" of 1D quasicrystals
might open a way to the RH.
a.text: grid and you draw a stripe of some
slope into the grid. Then projeting
the gridpoints that come to fall
within the stripe onto a say central
line of the stripe you obtain a 1D
S and L in the penrose tiling.
The analog works for Dan Shechtmans
they can be described as an
As far as I know it's open if
and project". In any case the
basic idea can be used to compute
that can be described like that.
the idea that the Riemann zeta
might open a way to the RH.

a.xlink:title:
Craig S. Kaplan
@csk
2023-03-21 14:17
--------------------------------
@VividConfusion @jsm28 Well, we
never said it looked like a kite --
it's made out of eight copies of
a small unit kite shape. We agree
that it looks like a shirt too,
but the hat won out in the end.
a.text: never said it looked like a kite --
it's made out of eight copies of
a small unit kite shape. We agree
that it looks like a shirt too,
but the hat won out in the end.

Benoît Régent-Kloeckner
@BrKloeckner@piaille.fr
2023-03-21 09:02
--------------------------------
@woody @csk There are several
possible definitions for several
subsets of the plane to have
"the same shape". The one that
seems most classical for tiling
is that they can be deduced
one from another through any
isometry (distance-preserving
transformation), including
mirror reflection. One reason
for that definition is that it
makes sense in any "metric
space", even those that do
not have a way to distinguish
orientation-preserving from
orientation-reversing isometries.
a.text: subsets of the plane to have
is that they can be deduced
for that definition is that it
not have a way to distinguish
the tile has to be flipped if
we wish to fill the plane?

Craig S. Kaplan
@csk
2023-03-21 02:00
--------------------------------
Taylor and Socolar came close
with their hexagonal tile. But
that shape requires additional
markings or modifications to tile
aperiodically, which can't be
encoded purely in its outline.

Socolar%E2%80%93Taylor_tile

a.xlink:title:
Tiota Sram
@tiotasram@kolektiva.social
2023-03-21 03:13
--------------------------------
@csk question (which might have an
answer out there I simply haven't
found it might not): I'm interested
in noise functions, and for various
purposes, an aperiodic noise
function would be swell. But true
noise functions need to be locally
evaluatable in time not related to
distance-from-origin. My gut as a
computer scientist tells me it is
not possible to have that property
and aperiodicity, and so far I've
settled on log-time algorithms as
a compromise. Do you know if it
had been proven either way that
aperiodicity is incompatible with
computable-at-arbitrary-coordinates-in-coordinates-independant
time?
(Or does this question even make sense
to you?)
a.text: answer out there I simply haven't
found it might not): I'm interested

function would be swell. But true

computer scientist tells me it is

and aperiodicity, and so far I've
a compromise. Do you know if it
had been proven either way that
(Or does this question even make sense

a.xlink:title:
Tiota Sram
@tiotasram@kolektiva.social
2023-03-21 03:32
--------------------------------
@csk actually, upon more thinking I
think there's a simple proof for
O(log(r)) being a lower bound for
time to compute an arbitrary patch
of an aperiodic tiling: if it's
deterministic (which I think it must
be), to get different outputs in
different places you need different
inputs, and coordinates which are
your inputs need log(r) bits (where
r is the distance from the origin),
all of which your algorithm must
depend on. I already have some
techniques for doing aperiodic
stuff in log-n time using fractal
coordinates, so I guess I've
answered my question here. But I'm
still curious what the big-O time
for computing an arbitrary patch
of these hats is as a function of
R. Naively I'd guess r-squared
(i.e., fill in a circle into you
get big enough to include r) but
I'd guess you could probably or
something O(r) together that filled
in a line from the origin... I
wonder if you can do better though?
a.text: think there's a simple proof for
O(log(r)) being a lower bound for
time to compute an arbitrary patch
of an aperiodic tiling: if it's
be), to get different outputs in
r is the distance from the origin),
all of which your algorithm must
depend on. I already have some
stuff in log-n time using fractal
answered my question here. But I'm
still curious what the big-O time
of these hats is as a function of
(i.e., fill in a circle into you
get big enough to include r) but
I'd guess you could probably or
in a line from the origin... I
wonder if you can do better though?

iirc. I would expect this to be
implementable in constant time
(but haven't tried this, so I
might talk nonsense right now).

a.xlink:title:
Greg Egan
@gregeganSF
2023-03-21 04:56
--------------------------------
@otherthings @tiotasram @csk

With the Penrose tiling, there are
details encoded in the coordinates
of the location where you are
computing the tiling that will
require more and more bits of
precision to maintain accurately
as you get farther away. I’ve
never really tried to quantify this
aspect of the tiling, though, and
it is not an issue for the applet
shown when run for, say, several
hours. But in the infinite limit
you would need ever more precision.
a.text: With the Penrose tiling, there are
of the location where you are
require more and more bits of
as you get farther away. I’ve
never really tried to quantify this
aspect of the tiling, though, and
it is not an issue for the applet
shown when run for, say, several
hours. But in the infinite limit
you would need ever more precision.

Cassidy Curtis
@otherthings@mastodon.social
2023-03-21 14:48
--------------------------------
@csk @gregeganSF @tiotasram The
other thing that could pose a
problem is that the Penrose tiles
are all aligned with certain axes,
so the resulting noise would still
have the same type of directional
biases that you get from any
grid-based noise. (Although maybe
adding more axes reduces the
bias? Hmm, now I’m curious!)

a.xlink:title:
Craig S. Kaplan
@csk
2023-03-21 02:03
--------------------------------
The paper includes two proofs
of aperiodicity. The first is a
computer-assisted, case-based
analysis of the structure of tilings
by hats. The second makes use of the
fact that the hat is one member of
a continuum of aperiodic monotiles!
https:/ / youtu.be/ W-ECvtIA-5A 6/ 6
a.text: of aperiodicity. The first is a
analysis of the structure of tilings
by hats. The second makes use of the
fact that the hat is one member of

2023-03-22 00:45

@Danpiker @csk @jsm28 Does it
actually loop? I can't find
any segment that doesn't go
outside this region in the image,
but thanks to being aperiodic
it's also not clear whether it
necessarily continues indefinitely.

I expect it wouldn't be too hard
to prove that sometimes there
is a loop, but it may be harder
to prove that even a single
loop is necessarily required.

was wrong. I've determined that
this is a hard problem after all."

a.xlink:title:
Craig S. Kaplan
@csk
2023-03-21 01:58
--------------------------------
How small can a set of aperiodic
tiles be? The first aperiodic set
had over 20000 tiles. Subsequent
research lowered that number,
to sets of size 92, then 6,
and then 2 in the form of the
famous Penrose tiles. https:/
/ youtu.be/ 48sCx-wBs34 1/ 6
a.text: How small can a set of aperiodic
tiles be? The first aperiodic set
and then 2 in the form of the

a.xlink:title:
Craig S. Kaplan
@csk
2023-03-21 01:58
--------------------------------
Penrose's work dates back to 1974.
Since then, others have constructed
sets of size 2, but nobody could
find an "einstein": a single shape
that tiles the plane aperiodically.
Could such a shape even exist?
https:/ / en.wikipedia.org/
wiki/ Einstein_problem
2/ 6
a.text: sets of size 2, but nobody could
Could such a shape even exist?

a.xlink:title:
Deborah Pickett
@futzle@old.mermaid.town
2023-03-22 05:14
--------------------------------
@csk This is amazing, and I have
just ordered the materials to
make a quilt based on tiling
hats, so watch this space!

A question, inspired by figure
2.12 in the preprint: at large
scale, can you always trace a path
from one F metatile to any other F
metatile through only F metatiles?
Similarly, from one H/ P metatile
to any other H/ P metatile through
only H/ P metatiles? My intuition is
that at most only one of these can
be yes, but they could both be no.
a.text: @csk This is amazing, and I have
make a quilt based on tiling
scale, can you always trace a path
from one F metatile to any other F
Similarly, from one H/ P metatile
to any other H/ P metatile through
only H/ P metatiles? My intuition is
that at most only one of these can
be yes, but they could both be no.

a.xlink:title:
Craig S. Kaplan
@csk
2023-03-21 17:45
--------------------------------
@stevenbodzin @Ianagol @jsm28 Yes,
you could manufacture tiles that
are *portions* of the hat. Eight
kites, or just four third-hexes.
Either way the unit cell would be
symmetric, so you could construct
hats and their reflections.
a.text: Either way the unit cell would be

a.xlink:title:
@Danpiker
2023-03-21 20:25
--------------------------------
@AntiPapa_Ken @csk @jsm28 You
can break this shape into
kites, but they have different
angles to the Penrose kites.
Penrose tiling requires 2
shapes. This new paper gets that
down to 1 (with reflections).
a.text: shapes. This new paper gets that
